article-meta.issue-title: Special issue of selected articles from ESREL 2011

abstract.p: The reliability and maintenance of offshore wind turbines present new challenges that demand novel, optimal, but at the same time cost effective, strategies to handle them. Wind turbines are installed in arrays and the combination of these arrays is called a wind farm. Owing to the wind loads and atmospheric conditions it is expected that certain wind turbines on the wind farm will behave similarly as they are located in close proximity. These similarities in the wind turbines need to be exploited at the wind farm level. To address this issue, a method is proposed to group different activities at both the intra and inter wind turbines at a wind farm level. Different kinds of tasks could be grouped together, such as inspection, preventive replacement at the wind farm level to share the access and travel costs from one wind turbine to another. To undertake these tasks, a hybrid approach of using the block replacement policy and condition-based model has been adopted to exploit the strengths of each approach. Moreover, using such a hybrid approach at the wind farm level, which groups different activities together, will act as a decision support tool that favors having an optimal strategy. By grouping different tasks at the wind farm level in conjunction with the hybrid approach will be advantageous by addressing the issues of access, logistics, transportation and weather in an efficient way. Moreover, this grouping of activities will to help optimize the frequency of visits to the wind farm and reduce the hazards related with risks and safety.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Nowadays there is considerable growth in the offshore wind turbine industry where different aspects, such as design, development, manufacturing, installation, and operation and maintenance (O&M) are being addressed for the challenging offshore environment. Different countries have taken strategic decisions for shifting their reliance from traditional sources of energy, like coal, oil, gas, and nuclear power to renewable sources of energy. This shift from traditional to renewable sources of energy has accelerated on a rapid scale, especially after the Fukushima incident in Japan quite recently. Among the renewable sources of energy, more and more attention is being paid to the installation of wind turbines. In this context, it has become imperative that wind energy should be relatively cheap and sustainable. This can only be achieved by developing and implementing cost-effective O&M strategies that are approximately one quarter of the total investment cost. Different ideas have been proposed for having optimal O&M strategies for wind turbines. These include using a condition monitoring system,1 condition-based maintenance,2 maintenance optimization based on a condition monitoring system with different issues from the economic point of view,3 the use of total productive maintenance, risk-based inspection, and reliability-centered maintenance,4,5 and the development of a maintenance optimization tool in connection with installation, access, and safety.6–8

Efforts are underway to address the operational challenges for conducting the inspection, preventive replacements, and repair of offshore wind turbines (OWT) to enhance their level of reliability and availability. Different approaches have been put forth, for example it has been proposed by Tian et al.9 how to use an artificial neural network in the maintenance optimization of OWT by continuously monitoring the signal condition. In Faulstich et al.10 the risk-related aspects during operation have been covered and this has discussed how the experience from onshore wind turbines can provide a sound basis for the optimal O&M strategies of OWT. The basis for conducting the grouping tasks of inspection and repair at the single wind turbine level has been provided by Hameed and Vatn.11,12

In short, a lot of research work is underway to handle and optimize the O&M strategies for OWT. The strategies have been suggested and subsequently optimized in a way to overcome the challenges being posed by the operations in an offshore environment. Few of these challenges are related to access, logistics, human safety, harsh weather, and ship collision. When addressing such challenges, most of the research has been focused on developing and implementing the O&M strategies for a single wind turbine. Moreover in planning the O & M strategies, the issues related with the set-up cost are not elaborated and exploited to its full extent. For example, what will happen while accessing the wind farm and what kind of hazards are present while traveling from one wind turbine to another with in a particular wind farm. Additionally, there is a need to plan a number of tasks when the vessel is going to the wind farm after paying the price for all hazards and risks present in accessing the wind farm and then traveling inside it. Such types of issues are not addressed in the available literature in detail. Thus these shortcomings were the motivation to write this article in order to cover different aspects and dimensions of sharing and exploiting the set-up cost by grouping different activities at the wind farm level to develop an optimal and cost-effective decision support tool. A combination of block replacement policy and condition-based model, in other words the hybrid approach, has been adopted to exploit and complement the respective strengths and weaknesses of each model. The proposed approach takes into account the impact of weather, access, logistics, and transportation in developing an optimal combination of a group of activities, which shows that the approach is flexible enough to incorporate any new and unforeseen information during the planning and implementation phases.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: The underlying principle of the current work is based on block replacement policy- and condition-based models like Weibull and PF (Potential failure point “P” to failure point “F”). These models are employed for estimating the effective failure rates of components before planning and executing inspection and maintenance activities. These tasks could be conducted by grouping different activities together at the wind farm level by implementing the grouping strategy by identifying which wind turbines are behaving similarly.

The grouping strategy is based on the block replacement policy (BRP), which is similar to age replacement policy (ARP). But in case of failure, the maintenance clock is not reset if the component is following BRP instead of ARP. It seems as if it is “wasting” some valuable component life time in the case of BRP, since the component is replaced at an age less than x (its maintenance interval) if a failure occurs in a maintenance period. However, this can be defended by the administrative savings or reduction of “set-up” cost if many components are maintained simultaneously, which provides a sound basis for grouping different components together. It has a direct implication for the components in wind turbines that are normally installed in the form of an array. The BRP approach provides the basis for conducting the grouping activities of various components either from the same or another wind turbine at the wind farm level. The average life of a single wind turbine is around 20 years, which suggests a long planning horizon that is suitable for the BRP approach. The set-up costs will be substantial when the wind turbines are operating in an offshore environment where the costs of access, logistics, and transportation are considerable. So in such type of situation, the use of BRP approach based on Weibull and PF models will probably outweigh, in such types of situations, the wastage of some useful life of a component vis-à-vis the savings incurred by sharing the set-up costs by a number of components from the number of wind turbines.

The PF, a time delay model, is based on the condition of the component rather than on its age. It is basically a time interval from the start of a serious failure say point “P” until the time when the failure occurs, say point “F”. So the duration from P to F is called PF interval. In the PF model, the criterion for declaring points P and F is very important. For the declaration of both points P and F, it is necessary to define the thresholds for these points when the state of the component will cross these limits. The determination of point “P” might be carried out in a better way by having discussions with the experts of the system. The condition of the component would be measured by conducting inspections and the results are to be shared with experts. Based on it, the experts would suggest about the occurrence of potential failure point P. When the experts agree that a potential failure is present, then there is a possibility to replace the component immediately. If this is not the case, then the inspection frequencies have to be enhanced to estimate the severity level of the failures. Based on such inspections, then one might be able to predict the occurrence of a failure point “F”.

In addition to Weibull, the inclusion of the PF model in the current work has been warranted by the fact that there are a number of components that could fail before their fixed life time or may be in good condition at their replacement time. So in both cases, i.e. earlier failure than actual life time or good operational conditions at their replacement time, suggest introducing the model based on the condition of the component for their maintenance activities. In such a scenario, the introduction of the PF model will play a pivotal role to exploit the useful life of the components and avoid the repercussions of their sudden failure. In this article we will refer to the BRP-based model as the Weibull model, since the Weibull distribution for failure times is often assumed. The principal approach will be identical also for other distributions, the only required change is to modify the formula for the effective failure rate.

The length of the PF model is assumed to vary from time to time owing to the fact that cracks might be initiated in different places on the component and the crack propagation depends on several different factors. The length of the PF model, TPF, should therefore be treated as a random quantity. The probability density function of the PF interval length, ξPF, will depend upon a set of explanatory variables. Periodic inspection is conducted at intervals of length x to detect potential failures. The length of the inspection intervals should not be longer than the average PF interval. This assumption is based on the fact that when the potential failure point P has been declared, it is better to replace the component immediately. If this is not the case, then the inspection interval should be less than the expected failure point F, which means that the inspection interval should not be longer than the expected PF interval. There is another basis for this assumption, which is that it is possible that the condition of the component might move from point P to F between the given inspection interval that could result in a failure. In such a case it is better to have a lower inspection interval than the expected PF interval of the component. It is worth mentioning here that the assumption has been carried out just to have an initial estimate about the expected duration of the inspection interval. But the actual inspection interval is to be obtained through the optimization process. Moreover the PF interval varies from time to time, so there is also a probability that a potential failure is not revealed during an inspection (that is the reason why the inspection interval should be shorter than the average PF interval). It is assumed that the PF interval is gamma distributed where the probability density function of gamma distribution with shape a > 0 and scale b > 0 is given by Rausand and Høyland13 as

where Γ(a)=∫0∞xa−1e(−x)dx is the gamma function and x > 0. The impact of the choice of distribution and the principles of how to establish parameters a and b is not discussed any further here. In the following we will refer to this model as the PF model.

Combining maintenance activities was first proposed by Dekker et al.14 almost two decades ago. It was suggested accomplishing the task of combining different maintenance activities by deriving the penalty functions, then the evaluations, and at the end obtaining the optimal combination of activities through a set partition algorithm. Afterwards, the work done by Wildeman et al.15 revolutionized the area of combining maintenance activities by proposing and discussing different aspects related with the grouping strategy. A parametric maintenance decision support tool was suggested by Castanier et al.16 where it was described how to group inspection or preventive replacement tasks of the two components together based on semi-regenerative properties of the maintained system states. The grouping of maintenance activities, based on the aging of the components, to the railway industry was proposed by Vatn.17 The grouping of different condition-based maintenance tasks was proposed by Bouvard18 for commercial heavy vehicles by estimating the ongoing degradation of the components. Financial issues, availability, and other aspects related with the grouping strategy were discussed by Van et al.19,20

The grouping strategy is divided into two types, one is called static and other is dynamic. The static regime is fixed over the time horizon and the number of components are also fixed. In the case of the dynamic strategy, the numbers of components are changing over the time horizon. The dynamic grouping strategy is complex in its implementation, but these complexities are being compensated by continuously including new and unforeseen information in order to develop an accurate scheduling of the maintenance tasks. Because of this advantage, the dynamic strategy is preferred to the static one in this article. It is worth mentioning that the current proposed grouping strategy is dynamic in the sense that the group size and the number of components in the given group are not static at all (as noted in Table 4 detailed later). There is another dynamic dimension that is linked with the proposed approach, this is how to the exploit the opportunities. There might be a number of reasons that could provide opportunities, like the sudden breakdown of the component (whether it is part of the coming group or not), and then the question arises about how to handle this new situation. In the same way, there might be a number of other such incidents or activities that could provide opportunities like the installation of new wind turbines in the same vicinity. When the initial groups have been established, then it is possible to handle all such situations in an optimal and rational way by splitting the groups if needed. Such aspects, regarding the handling of opportunities, are expected to be addressed in the near future. The basis of such future work will illustrate how the proposed method is sufficient to handle the opportunities in an optimal and dynamic way.

sec.title: Motivation
sec.p: First, it is important to have an overview of the operation of OWT as described in Figure 1, which provides the prime motivation for the current work. Weather, intrinsic reliability, access, and logistics are externally influencing factors over the O&M issues of OWT. Failure progression is influenced by the built-in reliability of the installed wind turbines. Moreover it is vital to understand the degradation of components in a marine environment to determine the estimated failure rates. Based on the failure rates, maintenance scheduling, execution, and opportunities will be exploited. In an offshore environment, the access and logistics are important variables that have a dominant influence on the maintenance optimization process. The optimality of the maintenance schedule would influence the expected number of failures, how many man hours are needed to fix the failures, and what was the reduction of downtime. The cumulative effect of external factors, optimality of maintenance scheduling, and exploitation of opportunities will determine the overall downtime, the impact on the environment, and the safety level adopted to conduct the inspection and repair tasks. At the end the overall cost of the whole operation will be determined.

caption.p: Outline of framework for maintenance optimization of OWT.

sec.p: As is shown in Figure 1, bearing in mind the geographic position of wind farms, access, logistics, and weather were considered significant factors that could influence the development of the optimal maintenance schedule. There are a number of ways to plan and implement the maintenance activities of OWT. In the current work, the focus was on the maintenance scheduling and then exploiting the opportunities. This work was completed by grouping different wind turbine components at the wind farm level. Grouping work is a part of scheduling and then by using the dynamic regime, the opportunities could be exploited.

Another motivation in this work is addressing the operational issues and challenges of OWT by proposing new ways to optimize the frequency of visits to the wind farm. This necessitates developing optimal maintenance strategies bearing in mind the weather, access, logistics, and transportation issues. It is very hard to put the condition monitoring system on all the wind turbine systems. Then it is necessary to identify which components offer better prospects to be monitored by using a condition monitoring system and which components are to be replaced after the completion of their operational age. The blend of age- and condition-based replacement for grouping will provide a reasonable basis to develop and manage the O&M strategies at the wind farm level. The establishment of the grouping activity will provide a basis to share the set-up cost for accessing the wind turbine and then the travel cost from one wind turbine to another. Moreover, sharing the set-up costs by grouping the components following the age- (Weibull) and condition-based (PF) approaches will provide a sound basis for viable operational strategies. Consequently the frequency of visits to the offshore wind farm will be optimized by not going for a single component, but for a number of components from single or many wind turbines. When the maintenance activities are planned and executed in this fashion, the issues of weather, access, logistics, and transportation will be handled with relative ease.

sec.title: Objectives
sec.p: There are number of objectives that can be achieved by implementing the proposed approach and some of them have been highlighted here.

list-item.p: It is expected that if the O&M strategies are planned and executed in the proposed way, the overall costs could be reasonably reduced by sharing the set-up costs.

The number of visits could be optimized, which will help in reducing the likelihood of accidents during accessing the wind farm and conducting the work on a wind turbine. In this way the risks related to occupational health and safety will be reduced significantly.
The availability of the wind turbines will be enhanced and per unit cost of energy production will be reduced by using the combination of age- and condition-based maintenance models.

The current approach will provide a basis to address the impact of weather and any other new or unforeseen information. Different combinations of group activities are possible that could be optimized to address the weather and other influencing variables on the optimal maintenance interval.
The proposed method will act as a means to exploit the opportunities that may arise owing to any ongoing activity at the wind farm level.

sec.p: The proposed method has addressed the outlined objectives (1) to (3) and has provided a strong foundation regarding how to handle the targets (4) to (5). It is planned to address the challenges and issues pertaining to objectives (4) and (5) based on the current approach in the near future. The reason for mentioning the last two objectives was to highlight the scope and relevance of the current approach in relation to the on-going operations of the OWT in an offshore environment.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: The limitation of the current work is the requirement of having extensive data to estimate the PF interval based on the condition monitoring or inspection data. The quantity of components might be large for the wind turbines at a particular wind farm. It may become cumbersome to define the PF interval for each and every component and then to conduct optimization to evaluate whether it is to be a part of a certain group or not.

sec.title: Grouping strategy at the wind farm
sec.p: When the maintenance activity is planned for a component, then the set-up cost “S” has to be paid for undertaking it. The more the components, the more “S” set-up costs that have to be paid for conducting any maintenance activity for every component. Consequently the sum of such costs S will be substantiated at the wind farm level where there are numbers of wind turbines installed with plenty of components. This cost S will be immense for OWT, where the factors such as weather, access, logistics, and mode of transportation will heavily influence the costs. So rather than paying S costs for every component separately, it is cost effective to find opportunities to share these costs by grouping the k activities of components together at a wind farm level. It means that rather than paying S set-up costs for every component separately, after grouping these costs will be reduced to S/k, which means more are the k activities together, the less will be the S set-up costs. Such means of sharing the costs S with k activities will pave the way for the reduction of the overall O&M costs over the total operational life of the wind turbines. Moreover when the dynamic regime is applied, then any new or unforeseen information is to be added in the implementation of grouping strategy, which will impart a more realistic picture to the results.

It is important to explore how the grouping strategy will be implemented at the wind farm level. There are a number of possibilities (1) consider the whole wind farm (2) cluster wind turbines based on the manufacturers, design type, failure rates, close proximities. Possibility (1) is appealing when the array of wind turbines is not very large, less than 10 turbines, but another scenario looks more attractive when the wind farm consists of large number of wind turbine, such as 20, 30, or more. In the case of the second possibility, one has to conduct the clustering analysis to demarcate the wind turbines that are behaving similarly. So rather than considering a huge array of wind turbines, the selected number of them should be picked based on the results obtained from the clustering analysis. The illustration of grouping strategy at the wind farm level by using Weibull and PF models is shown in Figure 2 where different grouping possibilities have been illustrated. Over the planning horizon, it is possible that the group may include the combinations of components, which are:

sec.p: Some of the important aspects pertaining to the grouping strategy of OWT are now outlined.

list-item.p: First of all, it will be prioritized to exploit all possible groups of combinations at the same wind turbine. The reason for this approach is to save the travel costs that have to be paid while going from one wind turbine to another. Plenty of time will be utilized in climbing up another wind turbine, putting the equipment there, starting the work, and then again climbing down. So if the number of wind turbines could be reduced to find the suitable set of activities, a considerable amount of time could be saved and be used for other tasks.

When we are searching for the same wind turbine, there is a possible combination of activities, such as those shown in Figure 2. Four possible combinations (lower ellipsis) are illustrated, for one single unit only, for four components. In a single wind turbine, there are hundreds of components, and evaluating and optimizing for a feasible set of activities becomes a complex problem from the computational point of view.

Both Weibull and PF models are employed in the current work. There is another challenge regarding the inspection results. Suppose the inspection results revealed the potential failure with a certain degree of risk. If the inspection results are obtained from the same wind turbine, then the problem may not become complex. But what happen if components are found with signs of failures with a fair amount of intensity in other wind turbines. Certain criteria have to be devised for going to other wind turbines versus the degree of failure progression. It is not a simple task to decide what to do in such a scenario.

A specification of the criteria for visiting another wind turbine compared with how many activities are to be conducted on a single turbine. This means that first of all it is necessary to evaluate whether it is feasible to approach another wind turbine or to stay with the first visited installation to do the work. Some yardstick has to be devised that will tell how many activities make it feasible to visit another one. Possible decisive parameters might be the travel cost from one wind turbine to another and then how many man hours are consumed before actually starting the work to fix the problem.

There is another challenge to decide the possible combination of activities based on the results of inspection that has to be conducted as part of the PF interval. There is the competition between visiting the number of wind turbines and the condition of the components in them. For example, there are number of activities that are to be completed on a wind turbine visited. Then what to do if there are only a few activities to be done in other wind turbines. Here the condition of those activities and the likelihood of sudden failure will play a crucial role in deciding whether to visit these turbines or wait until the next time for conducting the maintenance and inspection work.

In the wind farm, there is the possibility of a sudden breakdown in a wind turbine that could halt its operation. In this situation, emergency measures have to be adopted to approach the said wind turbine to fix the problem. Resources are to be utilized for such repair work that could be shared with other activities by evaluating which of the components could be shifted earlier to coincide with this work. This is another challenge that needs to be addressed in the formulation of the grouping strategy, which means that procedure has to be chalked out to handle such situations.

The preventive and corrective strategies are constrained by the weather, access, logistics, and other such variables while dealing with OWT as shown in Figure 1. The external variables pose a further challenge and make the problem complex in the implementation of the grouping strategy. For example, it is assumed that a tentative schedule has been optimized where certain activities are grouped together at a certain time. When the said time comes close to implementation, it is then found that there is no weather window. In this situation, what will be the strategy? One possible solution is to split the group in such a way to advance the activities that are for components that are not in a good condition, based on the results from the previous inspection, before the start of bad weather. This is an intuitive way of thinking, but more detailed analysis could be carried to approximate the levels of risk for such failure if the whole group of activities were to be carried out at the end of the bad weather.

sec.p: Some of the important challenges with respect to the grouping strategy are outlined here just to illustrate the complexity involved in their implementation at the wind farm level. There might be a number of other challenges that have to be addressed while dealing with the grouping strategy at the wind farm level when it comes to the implementation phase.

sec.title: Modeling framework
sec.p: In the modeling framework, our main attention has been focused on how to formulate the set-up costs in terms of accessing the wind farm, and then if needed, traveling from one wind turbine to another. We have also considered components following the Weibull- and PF-model approaches, respectively, and how the grouping strategy in a dynamic fashion will be undertaken and included in a description of the main steps of the heuristics.

sec.title: Set-up costs
sec.p: An offshore wind farm consists of an array of j wind turbines, where j = {1, 2, …}, the shape of which could be a straight line, rectangular, square, or circular. A wind turbine has components, i where i = {1, 2, …}, in a particular turbine j. Assume there are certain j turbines that are making a cluster of size nj. After determining the value of nj, the next work is to optimize the maintenance and inspection intervals of the components i in the turbines nj. Now consider a certain quantity of components i in turbine j that could be grouped together for undertaking the inspection and maintenance tasks together to share the set-up costs S for k groups of such activities. In the case of an offshore wind farm, the set-up cost, Saccess, has to be paid for accessing the wind farm. This cost is based on covering the distance (D) to access the wind farm from the coastal area and the paid cost per unit distance (Caccess) for using the access vessel as shown in Figure 3. Moreover, while accessing the wind farm, there exists the probability of an accident, say Pr(A), which may occur owing to weather conditions or collision with other passing ships, with a certain cost, Caccident. The time to access the wind farm, taccess, is dependent on the weather conditions that will influence all the parameters given in equation (2). For example, if there is rough sea and we have to access the wind farm, then there is more likelihood of accident. Moreover another influencing factor on the Saccess is the value of nj, because in case of its higher value, more vessels have to be arranged. In short, we have

sec.p: After accessing the wind farm, there is another set-up cost that has to be paid (if the need for it arises) being called Stravel. When the vessel (or vessels) has reached the wind farm, then there is a possibility to travel from j to j+1 turbines, for which we have to pay the travel cost, i.e. Stravel by paying the per unit travel distance cost Ctravel for covering the distance d. While traveling from one wind turbine to another, there is the probability, say Pr(B), of collision of the vessel with the wind turbine (or with another vessel in the vicinity if more than two vessels are hired) and the cost being paid would be Ccollision. The value of Stravel cost would be dependent on the same factors as it was for Saccess with only a slight difference of time to travel ttravel in place of taccess. Finally we get

Equation (3) states that given a group of activities k that consists of components i from only one wind turbine, i.e. nj = 1, then there will no travel cost that has to be paid. The vessel will directly approach the single wind turbine.
So the total set-up cost S will be the sum of accessing the wind farm and then traveling from one wind turbine to another, which could be given as

Equation (4) shows the dependencies among different parameters that play an important role in the estimation of the total set-up cost S. The number of wind turbines (nj), time to access (taccess), and travel ( ttravel) are important factors that have a heavy influence on the cost values related with access, travel, accident, and collision, i.e.{Caccess, Caccident, Ctravel, Ccollision}. Moreover, the duration of taccess and ttravel are dependent upon the weather conditions and the same fact has also been shown in Figure 1. The most influential factors of the weather in an offshore environment are the significant wave height (Hs) and wind speed (Ws), which would affect the operational time to access and then inspect and repair the system. In short, the time to access and travel are the function of significant wave height and wind speed, i.e. taccess = f(Hs,Ws) and ttravel = f(Hs,Ws). These two quantities (Hs, Ws) are random in nature and are not explicitly modeled in the current work, but are expected to be treated in future work. So in case of higher values of Hs and Ws, it might not be possible to access the wind farm by a normal boat and we have to hire a special vessel that would be appropriate for approaching the wind farm. A stage might arrive where the special purpose boat would not be a viable option and then there is a possibility to hire a helicopter for accessing the wind farm, either to conduct the inspection tasks or fixing the faults. Such kinds of situations suggest the dependence of taccess and ttravel on the weather conditions and show that the value S(.) would change from time to time owing to the weather conditions and how many wind turbines (nj) are part of the operation.

sec.title: Cost function
sec.p: The cost function will be derived to find the optimal time interval for the individual components at this stage. After formulating the set-up costs, the next issue is to model the failure rates of the components by using the Weibull and PF models. Both these models are based on the degradation of the component but the interpretation is different. In the case of the Weibull model, it is assumed that the degradation increases as the time passes and it will reach its maximum until the mean time to failure (MTTF) of the component. But in the case of the PF model, which is assumed to follow the gamma distribution, condition of the component should be inspected over and over again, and then the decision will be made about its replacement irrespective of its age. In this case, the time for the next inspection is decided on the basis of the current condition and the inspection frequencies will depend upon the degree of deterioration.

For each component i in turbine j, there is an expected degradation cost owing to failures within a defined time interval [0,x]. First we assume that the cost related to a failure, cijr, (cost of failure) is independent of the age of the component at the time of failure. Next we assume that a component will be “as good as new” after maintenance. Finally repair times are short compared with failure times. Thus we have the expected degradation cost owing to failure as
where λE,ij(x)Weibull is the effective failure rate of component i in turbine j preventively maintained at intervals of length x.

There is an inverse relationship between the failure rate (λ) and MTTF, i.e. λ=1/MTTF. It means that if the component i has a higher MTTF, then its failure rate (λ) would be less or vice versa. This relationship between λ and MTTF is very simple, which needs precision to improve this formulation. One way is to estimate the failure rate by developing a relationship between the interval (x) and the MTTF. Bearing in mind this relationship, an approximation would be obtained to estimate the effective failure rate λE,ij(x)Weibull, shown in equation (5). There are ways to estimate the value of the effective failure rate λE,ij(x)Weibull based on the relationship between the interval (x) and MTTF. When the component i from turbine j has been put into operation, then it starts consuming its operational life thus reducing its MTTF. Equation (6) is not a good approximation if x > 0.1 MTTF. In such a case, equation (6) would be used with a correction factor being proposed by Chang et al.21 to approximate the effective failure rate, when the interval (x) is up to 0.5 MTTF and is given as

In equation (7), the second part is the value of the correction factor that has been incorporated to enhance the precision in the calculation of the effective failure rate λE,ij(x)Weibull. When the interval (x) is greater than 0.5 MTTF, then no suitable approximation is available to estimate the effective failure rate λE,ij(x)Weibull. In such a situation, the renewal function, Wren(x), has to be implemented to calculate the effective failure rate based on the convolution approximation as proposed by Rausand and Høyland.13 Then, the effective failure is given as λE,ij(x)Weibull = Wren(x)/x.

If the component i is following the Weibull model, then as per BRP it will be replaced by paying the preventive maintenance cost cijp. So during this process of preventively replacing the components, it will be considered whether to include other k activities for sharing the S set-up cost from components i in wind turbine j. This exercise would be carried out to share the set-up cost S with as many k activities as possible. The value of k is to be determined based on the fact that how many kj number of i components are selected from j wind turbines where kj is the sum over components i being considered candidates for a certain group from wind turbines j. The kj group of components would be selected from those nj number of wind turbines that are being considered to be visited for carrying out the inspection and maintenance activities. Let us assume that we have five wind turbines (J = 5), three of out of them are selected to be visited (nj = 3), and each of them has eight components (I = 8). Now we have to make an initial guess regarding the expected number of components i that might be part of the group kj from the selected nj wind turbines. Suppose that from the first nj wind turbine, there are three components to be considered for becoming part of group (kj = 3), from the second wind turbine, four components (kj = 4), and from the last one, two components (kj = 2). Then the value of k is 9 because it is the sum over kj components from nj wind turbines. The relationship among k, kj, and nj can be generalized as k=Σj[kj+(nj-1)kj]. It is worth mentioning that if there is one wind turbine being considered for visiting purposes, i.e. nj = 1, then the value of k would be determined based on only the single wind turbine and the second part would vanish. In such a case, the expected value of k might be less because it would only be determined from the single turbine. On the other hand, if the value of nj is large, then there are more chances for having a higher value of k. It cannot generalized because there is a possibility for having more components to be grouped together (higher value of k) from a single machine based on the condition and operational life of them compared with the same from a number of wind turbines (higher value of nj). In short, the value of k depends upon the amount of inspection and maintenance being considered for the number of machines that would help in finding the suitable number for it. So, the total S set-up cost would be divided by the group of k activities to lower the overall operational cost. Therefore, the cost function, Φij,Weibull(x), could be given as

It is true that degradation starts increasing with the age for some components, but this is not always the case. There are components whose degradation is not strongly linked to age. So the degradation estimation of such components has to be carried out by collecting the data for determining their condition. By using such data it is important to determine the potential failure point (P) till it goes to failure point (F), which could be undertaken by using the PF interval model. The determination of point P might be carried out, for example, by using the techniques based on vibration, acoustics, pressure, and temperature. Moreover the analysis of lubrication oil and debris may provide useful information about the on-going state of the components. In short the point P is able to be evaluated based on the on-going condition of the component. For example, if we are getting the vibration signal of a bearing and if its condition is good, then amplitude of the vibration signal would be in the allowable limits. But as the condition of the bearing starts deteriorating, the amplitude of the vibration signal would start entering in the yellow range. Now the point P has been determined after discussing with the experts, then the next task is to estimate when the point F would occur. The path from point P to F may follow different paths (a few of them are shown in Figure 4), so it seems quite reasonable to treat the PF interval as the random variable. Additionally it is important to increase the inspection frequencies after the point P has been determined to estimate when the point F might occur for taking preventive measures.

PF: potential to failure; MTTF: mean time to failure.

sec.p: When the component is put into operation, then it is expected that it will be in operation for a considerable period of time without any sign of potential failure. After the completion of its expected good operational life, the indications start arriving about the presence of a potential failure, which is denoted as point P in Figure 4. The time to reach this potential failure point (Tp) is a random quantity. The expected time to reach this potential failure point P would be E(Tp). The value for E(Tp) might vary from one component to another owing to different factors, such as the design, environment, and maintenance. When the signs of potential failure have been revealed, then there are a number of paths available to reach the failure point and some of them are highlighted in Figure 4. Thus the time from potential failure point P to failure point F is a random quantity with its expected value of E(PF). It is expected that the time to failure point F would not occur before the MTTF, which means that the whole operational life of the given component would be exploited. But as there is also a chance to have failure point F occurring within the given MTTF of the component, the quantities of time to potential failure (Tp) and the duration of PF interval (PF) are treated as random variables.

It is assumed that component i from turbine j has been in operational phase without any signs of potential failure. After a while, there were indications emerging regarding the potential failure point P as shown in Figure 4. Thus the time to potential failure of the component i from turbine j is denoted as E(Tp)ij, which is a random quantity. After point P is decided there are a number of possibilities concerning the occurrence of failure point F. The time from point P to F is denoted as the PF interval with its expected value of E(PF)ij for component i from turbine j. The value of MTTF of component i from turbine j is denoted as MTTFij. If the value of E(PF)ij and MTTFij are known, then it is easy to calculate the value of E(Tp)ij, which is given as E(Tp)ij=MTTFij–E(PF)ij. On the other hand, if we do not have any idea about the value of E(PF)ij, then it is not easy to approximate the value of E(Tp)ij. In such a case we use operational data, or carry out the discussions with the experts regarding the likelihood of the E(PF)ij value.

In the present work, it is assumed that the PF interval is gamma distributed with E(PF)ij and SD(PF)ij as mean and standard deviations, respectively. So if we know the values of E(PF)ij and SD(PF)ij, it is not difficult to estimate the shape (a) and scale (b) parameters of the gamma distribution. The value of shape and scale parameters will tell us how fast the PF path will hit the failure point F and the time spent during this process. The values of shape and scale parameters are directly linked with E(PF)ij and SD(PF)ij as E(PF)ij=a/b and SD(PF)ij=a/b2. So if we know the values of E(PF)ij and SD(PF)ij, then it is relatively straightforward to calculate the shape (a) and scale (b) parameters. As the PF interval may follow different paths, this shows that it is a random variable with TPF. Owing to the random nature of the PF interval and the limitations of the inspection method (a given inspection technique may fail to detect the initiation of failure or failure altogether), it is important to have the inspection interval x shorter than the PF interval (TPF). However, the optimality of the inspection interval can be obtained through the optimization process. So when the inspection is carried out, there is a probability that a potential failure is not detected by the selected inspection method. The probability that the inspection strategy fails to reveal a potential failure before a critical failure occurs, could be found by using the law of total probability as

where Qt(x,q,t) is the probability of not detecting a potential failure given that the PF interval, TPF, equals t, x is the inspection interval, q is the failure probability of one inspection, i.e. the probability that a given inspection method fails to detect a potential failure, and finally ξPF (t) is the probability distribution function of TPF. The term Qt(x,q,t) could be approximated when TPF = t, when the number of possibilities to detect a failure equals h or h+1 where h=int(t/x) and int(.) is the integer function. The probability that we will have h+ 1 possibilities equals t/x – h and thus the probability that we will have h possibilities to detect a potential failure equals h+1 – t/x. Since the probability that a given inspection fails to detect a potential failure equals q, Qt(x,q,t) could be obtained by
By using equation (11), the estimation of Q0(x,q,ξPF) can be carried out.

In the case of the PF interval, the value of effective failure, say λE,ij(x)PF, of component i from turbine j will depend on how many potential failure points P occur and the accuracy of the inspection method used in their detection. It is assumed that a certain inspection method has been used to detect the occurrence of point P, however it failed to do it. This failure of the inspection method will be approximated by the functional term of Q0(x,q,ξPF) given in equation (10). If Q0(x,q,ξPF) is the probability of not detecting an abnormality or crack and (fp)ij is the frequency of failure of component i from turbine j, then the effective failure rate owing to the PF interval, λE,ij(x)PF, is given as

where (fp)ij =1/E(Tp)ij =1/MTTFij–E(PF)ij. The value of (fp)ij is based on how many potential failure points P have been detected during the given length of the PF interval per unit time. So if there are more P points during the given interval, it means that the system is more prone to failure. Additionally, the expected length of the PF interval, i.e. E(PF)ij has a direct influence on the value of (fp)ij. The value of MTTFij is determined based on the expected survival rate of component i over the period of time, i.e. how many hours, months, or years a component could be expected to survive in an operational state before its failure. If the value of MTTFij is treated as fixed, then the higher the value of E(PF)ij would likely result in a higher value for (fp)ij or vice versa. For instance, a component i has 10 months of operational life (i.e. MTTFij=10) and if it has started to show the existence of potential failure points P at earlier stage (assume E(PF)ij=5), then it has a higher susceptibility for earlier failure (fp=0.2). On the other hand, if a similar component experiences the signs of potential failure point P at a later stage (assume E(PF)ij=2), then it has less chance to fail earlier (fp=0.12). It is pertinent to mention that the value of (fp)ij would only be determined if we successfully conduct the inspections and find the potential failure points P and then the value of E(PF)ij.

After determining the effective failure rate λE,ij(x)PF, the next step is to develop the cost function Φij,PF(x) of component i in turbine j. In the cost model, a certain inspection activity for component i in turbine j is executed with a cost of cijI+S, where cijI and S are the inspection and total set-up costs, respectively. It is proposed that the cost element S should be shared by the group of k activities (the values of S as in equation (4), and k is the same as being used for Weibull model in equation (8)). So the cost function is given as

The first part in equation (13) states that the S set-up cost would be shared by k group of activities in addition to paying cijI inspection costs during the interval x. The second part of equation (13) represents the expected degradation cost owing to failure based on the PF interval, which is further expanded in equation (14), based on equations (10) and (12)

The first part of equations (14) and (15) are similar to that shown in equation (13). The effective failure rate based on the PF interval λE,ij(x)PF, being estimated in equation (12), has been given in the third part of equation (14), which shows that the failure cost cijr has to be paid if the inspection method fails to detect the failure. But contrary to this, the second part of equation (14) states that if the inspection method succeeded in revealing the signs of failure, which is (1– Q0(x,q,ξPF)), then cijp, the cost of preventively replacing the component, has to paid. Based on these facts, equation (14) can be modified as

The success in revealing the potential failure and then replacing the component preventively shows the renewal process, which is highlighted in the second part of the equation (15) by wren,ij(x)PF. The last part of equation (15) represents the effective failure rate, λE,ij(x)PF, being estimated in equation (12), which shows the cost of failure cijr has to be paid in case of not detecting the failure. Equation (15) shows the dependence of the final cost function on the renewal rate, effective failure rate, set-up costs, inspection, preventive, and corrective replacement costs. It is evident that the values of wren,ij(x)PF and λE,ij(x)Failure will significantly influence the final cost function. This is based on the fact that their values will be based on the time E(Tp) for detecting the potential failure points P, the duration of the PF interval E(PF)ij, frequency of failure (fp), and the success of the inspection method. In short, all these factors will significantly influence the optimal inspection interval in addition to the costs being incurred owing to inspection, preventive, and corrective tasks.

sec.title: Formulation of grouping strategy
sec.p: After determining the optimal interval (xij*) for individual components for inspection and maintenance activities, the next task is to establish the group of components that could be inspected and maintained together. When setting up the grouping, the optimal intervals (xij*) of the components will be shifted to another “optimum” time (tij*) for group execution. In the total list of components, some will be shifted to this new optimum time but for some components, this new time will not be cost effective. A penalty has to be paid for the components that will be shifted from their original optimal time (xij*) to a new optimum time (tij*) for becoming part of a group. Methods have been proposed to approximate the penalty, one was described in Wildeman et al.15 and the other in Vatn,17 which considered how to calculate the penalty for grouping based on marginal thinking. The latter approach has been implemented in the current work and a possible extension at the wind farm level has been discussed and outlined here.

Let Φ*ij,k be the minimum average costs of a component i in wind turbine j for an activity k when one component is considered individually, and let x*ij,k be the corresponding optimum x value. Assume that the time now is t0, and xij is the age (time since last maintenance or last inspection) for component i in turbine j being considered for a group. Further assume that the planning horizon is [t0, T]. The problem now is to determine the time t (≥t0) when the next maintenance or inspection is to be executed. The total costs of executing the inspection and maintenance activities in a group are S +ΣjΣi cijI and S +ΣjΣi cijP, respectively, which we pay at time t. During the search for a new time t, where a number of k activities could be grouped together, there are uncertainty costs that we might have to pay while delaying the maintenance or inspection activities from their due optimal time (xij*) to the new time (t). This means that if the component has survived till the current time t0 and if we are searching for a new time t where it could be grouped together with other components, then during the time interval [t0,t], there is a chance of failure. This likelihood of failure during interval [t0,t] should be catered for in terms of how much risk is affordable versus exploiting savings in terms of sharing the S set-up costs with k group of activities. So, the expected unplanned costs in period [t0,t] for a component i in turbine j is ΣjΣiMij,Weibull(t–t0+xij) –ΣjΣiMij,Weibull(xij) and ΣjΣiMij,PF(t–t0+xij) –ΣjΣiMij,PF(xij) for the Weibull and PF models, respectively. For the remaining time of the planning horizon, the total costs are (T–t) ΣjΣiΦ*ij,k provided that each component i can be maintained at “perfect match” with k–1 activities during the rest of the period. Since Φ*ij,k depends on how many components i from wind turbines j share the S set-up cost for accessing and traveling from one wind turbine to another one at the wind farm level for conducting the inspection and repair tasks, which we do not know at this time, we use an average value Φ*ij,Av. Bearing in mind this aspect the point of time, when this average cost Φ*ij,Av would be minimum, can be denoted as x*ij,Av. Moreover, we assume that we know this average value in the first planning.

At the wind farm it is assumed there are J turbines. From these J turbines a large number of possible subsets can be formed to include them in the next group of maintenance activities. Now let N1, N2,… be possible sets of turbines, e.g. N1 = {1}, N2 = {1,2}, N1 = {2,3}, etc., referring to Figure 2. Further let Kk,j be the set of the k first due activities for turbine j. In order to form candidate groups for the activities to include in the next maintenance group, we need, in principle, to consider all possible subsets N1, N2, …, and then for a given subset, say Nl we need to consider all possible values of k in order to determine Kk,j. Heuristics are required to make a reasonable screening of possibilities to include in the comparison in order to obtain the best group. Thus the total future cost of the components/activities included in the candidate group we are testing is given by

Note that two sets of equations are provided to treat the Weibull and the PF models separately. They need to be combined in such a way that the set-up cost S is not included twice. The information given in equation (16) is straightforward when considering the replacement based on age by using the Weibull model. But what will happen if the condition of certain components is not satisfactory and the inspection results have shown the presence of potential failure while following the PF model as in equation (17). If the inspection has already revealed a potential failure, then in this situation there will be an additional risk not covered by the Mij,PF(.) function, which is the likelihood that a component is not performing its intended role although it is still an operational condition. So there is a probability that the component might not perform at the desired levels of its expected output. This situation is captured by introducing a new term called time to failure (TTF), which is considered as the end of the useful life of a component. The term TTF is a random variable that depends on the age of the potential failure, i.e. what is the time since the potential failure was initiated in order to approximate the age of potential failure, it is possible to introduce 2, 3, or 4 virtual states of the failure progression. Then, given a virtual state, it is possible to have probability distribution regarding TTF. For example, if the state is that the potential failure has occurred “almost” recently, then the probability density function (pdf) of TTF would be close to the original PF interval, but when the state is “bad” another pdf has to be derived. Then, the risk would be Pr(TTF<t) with accompanied cost of failure, i.e. cijr.

There is a possibility that certain components might not become part of a group, we assume that they will be inspected or maintained at their optimum time t*i,Av > t. The total contribution to the costs related to these activities in [t0, T] is

provided they can be maintained at “perfect match” with other activities, i.e. the set-up costs are shared with (kij,Av– 1) activities, and executed at time t*ij,Av at the wind farm level. Here Kk,j = ∅ (the empty set) if j∉Nl. The total optimization problem related to the next group of activities is therefore to minimize

In order to establish the group of activities, equation (20) is to be used to determine which activity should be included in the group, i.e. maintenance and inspection, respectively. The idea is simple; we first determine the best group to execute next for the given number of wind turbines, and the best time to execute the activities. Further, we assume that subsequent activities can be executed at their local optimum. It is expected to do better by taking the second grouping into account when planning the first group, and not just treating the activities individually. The candidate groups are found by starting with the activity with the lowest tentatively execution time, and trying to group it together with the next activity. This forms the first candidate group, consisting of two activities with a maximum saving of S and so on. The search for new candidate groups stops when the savings starts dropping when the new activity is included.

sec.title: Heuristics
sec.p: The formulation of the grouping of activities across the wind farm level is not an easy task. A procedure for the implementation of the proposed grouping strategy is outlined in the following steps.

sec.title: Step 0
sec.p: Initialization process is undertaken as the starting point. Initial estimate for the value of k has to be accomplished. It means to find the average number of activities that consists of the first wind turbine j visited and other ones to search for undertaking inspection and maintenance work. Based on this average value of k, the initial estimate for xij* and respective Φij* are established for the Weibull and PF models based on equations (9) and (15), respectively. It is important to decide the starting point, i.e. t0=0 and the end of the planning horizon (T).

sec.title: Step 1
sec.p: The group of activities is defined in such a way that it will start from the first turbine j visited and then go to other j+1 ones, where j ϵ Nn. For this purpose, the time for group execution tij* is defined, i.e. t*ij = x*ij+ t0 – xij for activities following the Weibull model and t*ij = x*ij+ t0 – tPF for the PF model, where tPF is the value of the PF interval.

sec.title: Step 2
sec.p: Search for the possible candidate groups Kk, where Kk could be the kth set, among some possible candidate groups, i.e, K1, K2, …, KK. start from the visited turbine Nn, e.g. Nn could be the nth visited wind turbine. A candidate group is the combination of activities that may consist from a number of wind turbines. All possible candidate groups Kk are to be evaluated for their viability from Nn wind turbines, which means having to search in different dimensions to find an optimal combination of activities. While exploring a certain Nn wind turbine, a point of time may be reached beyond which adding more activities might not be feasible. Then the search has to be started looking for other Nn+1 turbines for evaluating the optimality of including certain activities at them. While moving from Nn to Nn+1, the travel cost and other costs necessary for starting the work (if applicable, like the transportation of heavy spare parts, tools, etc.) might play a critical role in deciding the feasibility of visiting the turbines or not. It is important to evaluate how many activities could be included from the other wind turbines to hold this condition, i.e. c(t,k)Nn+1 < c(t,k)Nn both for the Weibull and PF models, as in equation (20). This implies that another wind turbine will only be visited when it really pays off in terms of bearing the travel and other related costs.

sec.title: Step 3
sec.p: The search for candidate groups Kk for turbines Nn is to be accomplished based on the tij* values. This search is conducted in such a way to find best possible time when maximum activities could be grouped together from turbine Nn turbine to Nn+1. During that search, if the time of group execution t*k > min j<n, i<k (t*ij+x*ij), then the search for more candidate groups will be stopped to avoid the duplication of activities.

sec.title: Step 4
sec.p: The activities in the candidate group are determined by minimizing c(t,k) as in equation (20) with respect to the execution time tij* of the group. In this process, it is possible to have the same kind of activities (inspection or maintenance) or a mixture of them (inspection and maintenance) depending upon the initial established time interval x*ij. Group Kk is established after this optimization process, which is planned to be executed at its optimum time tij*.

sec.title: Step 5
sec.p: Upon detecting the potential failure after inspection by using the PF model, the execution of the next activities is considered to be modified, i.e. time t for activities i in turbine j is subject to certain changes in a group. The time intervals between the execution of group activities, say Δt, is shortened to increase the frequency of inspections to monitor the failure intensity. At time t, when the potential failure is detected, the next candidate group Kk is chosen in such a way that a group of activities starts from turbine j as j ϵ Nn where it is detected. In this case, inspection tasks are prioritized compared with maintenance tasks in the same turbine j to avoid sudden breakdown.

sec.title: Step 6
sec.p: Candidate groups Kk are established for the execution of activities at their optimum time t. This means that for activities that are following the Weibull model, xij =0 for jϵ Nn, iϵKk, and xij=xij+t–t0 for i∉Kk updating the current time t0=t. The activities that are following the PF model, the inspection results are satisfactory, if there is no sign of potential failure, then TTF=0, otherwise, find the value of TTF.

sec.title: Step 7
sec.p: The process continues until t0 < T, otherwise the grouping task has come to its logical conclusion.

In the heuristic we assume that activities that are not included in the first group to execute, could be executed at their “individual” optimum. This seems reasonable in the one dimensional phase when there is only one system. But here there are a number of wind turbines and each turbine has plenty of activities to be performed. This kind of situation necessitates conducting a bulk search to find the optimal group of activities across the wind farm. We essentially apply a “greedy” algorithm only considering the first group that may stack problems in forming the subsequent groups. It might be that the algorithm only aims to find what is best to do now, and ignores the possibility that it may be harder to find good groups later on, i.e. if the result of the “greedy search” leaves “single” activities in a lot of turbines, this will then be very expensive for the next group. This is not discussed further in this article.

The proposed method gives an interesting insight into planning and optimizing of the groups at the wind farm level. Additionally, such schemes for including a second, third, etc., wind turbine in the groups will provide a basis to decide whether paying the travel cost from one wind turbine to another is feasible or not. There are a number of scenarios and associated potential for opportunities while working with the grouping strategy. After establishing the initial groups, then upon the availability of new information proper heuristics can also be developed to evaluate the viability of modifying the group of activities.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: It is worthwhile understanding how a wind turbine works, what are the main components, and what could be the possible cause of malfunctioning. For the current study, a gearbox along with its cooling system and two other components are selected as an example to demonstrate the implementation of the proposed grouping strategy. A typical wind turbine is shown in Figure 5. A deeper understanding of the system can be obtained by using the standard failure mode effect and cause analysis technique, an example of such work was done by Arabian-Hoseynabadi et al.23

sec.p: In the current work, it is assumed there are three wind turbines, i.e. nj=3 at this stage. Then the failure rates of different components were estimated using the Weibull and PF models. The wind farm has to be accessed and the respective cost has to be paid by employing equation (2), which is assumed to be 1500€. If the work has to be done on more than one wind turbine, then the additional travel cost has to be paid by following equation (3), which was assumed to be 500€. After determining the failure rates and set-up costs, the interval was optimized by using equations (9) and (15) for components that are following the Weibull and PF models, respectively, as shown in Table 1.

caption.p: Determination of interval optimization for the components of the given wind turbines.

fn.p: MTTF: mean time to failure; PF: potential to failure; PM: inspection and maintenance; CM: corrective maintenance.

sec.p: After determining the individual optimal interval xij*, the next task is to group the components among the given number of wind turbines that are following different degradation models for the estimation of failure rates. For the establishment of groups, equation (20) was implemented to optimize the group of activities that could be planned together. For the accomplishment of this process, heuristics was used to evaluate different combinations of activities before selecting an optimal group. Initially it was assumed that over the planning horizon T, which is considered to be 48 months, on average half of the activities could be grouped together, i.e. k=12 (there are three wind turbines, each has eight components, so the total activities are 24). The results of grouping maintenance and inspection activities together for different components were established over the given planning horizon. The groups were established by shifting the components from their individual optimal time (xij*) to a new time (tij*) to adjust as many components as possible through optimization. The components were grouped together until finding an optimal time (tij*) for a number of activities. A typical example of a group of activities is shown in Table 1.

The formulation of the grouping activity starts from the heat exchanger of wind turbine (WT) number 3. Then the search first goes to find other activities to be part of the same group. It explored all possible combinations from the given number of three wind turbines. In this search, in total k=14 activities were found to be optimal to be conducted together at time tij*=3.50 months. Afterwards, the cost started to increase, which shows that it is no longer feasible to include other activities in the group. The formulation of the first group of activities shows that inspection and maintenance (PM) activities are to be chosen from all three wind turbines. In the current work, the number of wind turbines and components chosen were, respectively, three and eight, which are small numbers considering the number of installed machines in the wind farm.

When the types of activities were analyzed from Table 2, then it was clear that four activities are PM related, while others were inspection out of the total 14. This means that the ratio between PM and inspection is almost 1:3, which is valuable information, because half of the activities are following the Weibull and PF models, but the ratio among them is one to three. This implies that more inspections are to be carried out to estimate the condition of the components to identify signs of any potential failure. Like the ratio in group one, almost the same ratio of maintenance and inspection is dominant in the other 13 combinations of activities until the end of the planning horizon, i.e. T=48 months.

caption.p: Group of activities based at the wind farm level.

fn.p: PM: inspection and maintenance; WT: wind turbine.

sec.p: The total number of groups with details of activities and size are shown in Table 3. The average number of activities over the planning horizon was assumed to be 12, i.e. kassumed=12 and the actual average value of k was found as 15, i.e. kactual=15. The difference between kassumed and kactual is not too large, which means that our initial guess, in assuming half of the activities (i.e. 12 from the total 24) will be part of a group on average, was found to be quite reasonable. But this fact should not be generalized upon when considering the large number of components from a number of wind turbines. Still, it is reasonable to start from half of the activities and then calculate the actual value of k. Moreover, the average change in the number of activities, i.e. Δk was found to be six while moving from one group to another over the whole planning horizon. The value of Δk could also be a good indicator to evaluate the possible fluctuations in the group of activities, which might prove valuable information while planning activities.

caption.p: Summary of group activities till the planning horizon at the wind farm level.

sec.p: While analyzing the group of activities over the planning horizon in Table 3, it was found that all groups were filled with inspection and maintenance activities from all the wind turbines. Moreover, the average change in the time from one group to another, i.e. Δtij* was found to be four months approximately. This value is reasonable as it says that the wind farm has to be visited on average three times in a year to inspect and fix the maintenance issues. The visiting frequency of three a year is not too much as it is manageable from access, logistics, and repair points of view. The only issue is how to address the weather when the group execution is due. Then it is possible to delay the group execution until the next group if the condition of the component is not too serious. On the other hand, if the condition of some components is serious, then the group could be split and prioritized so as to do the important tasks, either before or after the bad weather. In short there are a number of scenarios that can be handled by conducting the O&M functions by following the grouping strategies. Plenty of opportunities could also be exploited by adjusting the group of activities in a number of ways. For example, it may be possible that one wind turbine will be shut down and it has no component in the coming executed group activity. Then, owing to this new development, it may be possible to advance the execution of a group for another wind turbine when fixing the failure in the turbine that is down.

The established groups in Table 3 are of a dynamic nature in contrast to the static regime in two distinct ways. First the value of activities k is varying from one group to another, and second the number of components in every group is not a fixed quantity. For this purpose, the detail of groups at Sr. No. 1, 2, 3, and 4 from Table 3 are shown in Table 4. Before interpreting the component details in Table 4, it is important to know that the average time difference from one group to another is approximately four months, i.e. Δtij*=4 months. Moreover, it is of paramount importance to bear in mind the optimal individual maintenance or inspection interval xij* of each component from Table 1. From this table, it is quite evident that the average individual optimal interval of components, which follow the PF interval, is 3.92 months, which is quite close to the value of Δtij*. It might be possible that owing to this closeness there are more chances for the components that are following the PF model to appear more frequently in the groups, see for example “WT 03_Main Bearing+”. But on the other hand, the components that are following the Weibull model, their inclusion in the groups seems more dynamic, see for example “WT 01_Motor*” and “WT 01_Cooling fan**”. It is worth mentioning that if the individual optimal intervals xij* of the components would be close together, there is more chance that these components would appear more often together in the planned group. One way to see the dynamic nature of groups is to have more operational data. Based on that data, the necessary parameters can be approximated, representative of the Weibull and Gamma distributions (MTTF, α, a, b, q).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The proposed method of grouping different activities together provides a sound basis to reduce the O&M costs at the wind farm level. The frequency of visits to the wind farm could be reduced significantly by grouping different activities together.

A tentative schedule of inspection and maintenance activities has been planned and optimized over the planning horizon. The present planning horizon is 4 years (48 months), which provides sufficient grounds for maintaining the proper stock levels of extra components and accessories for repair, developing the optimal fleet size of access vessels, and transporting the necessary equipment for the replacement or inspection purposes. Moreover, the tentative scheduling in the form of groups gives the decision maker an overall picture for advance planning. This will play an important role in managing the safety, downtime, uncertainties, and other such issues on a broader scale.

The blend of age- and condition-based strategies (Weibull and PF) is another salient feature of the proposed grouping scheme. The exploitation of the proposed blend could provide sound basis to avoid wasting the operational life of those components that are easy to be inspected and then simultaneously replacing those ones that are not too costly to be replaced upon reaching their specified age.

The implementation of the dynamic grouping strategy is full of challenges and complexities, especially for offshore wind farm operations because these are complex compared with land-based wind turbines. Stringent efforts are required to decide about the degradation models for wind turbine components in the marine environment. Additionally, it is demanding how to decide which component would follow the age- or condition-based models and what are the implications of such decision on the formulation of the grouping strategy. Heuristics for solving the grouping strategy are posing new challenges in terms of how to evaluate the feasible sets of the group of activities under the given constraints of vessel, transportation, safety, and downtime. In short there are a number of challenges and issues that need to be addressed for the refinement and improvement of the dynamic grouping strategy by employing strenuous efforts while bearing in mind the offshore environment of the wind turbines.

The proposed approach has provided a sound basis to exploit the opportunities and handle unforeseen information, but still a lot of work is required in order to demonstrate how it could be carried out. This is another type of challenge that needs further investigation and demonstrates that the approach is dynamic in managing the O&M strategies of the offshore wind farms in an optimal way. This type of work is expected to be completed in the near future.
